subject: Re: Test Names and rerunning Test instances for Parameterized Tests
msgSnippet: ... I found, upon looking into it, that Eclipse does have the /option/ of keeping the JUnit process/JVM running, so it can restart individual test instances.

--- Eugene Kuleshov <eu@m...> wrote:
>    Thank you for cheching this. But =
exactly this sequence does
> not work for me and never worked giving the er=
rors like this:
> 
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Could not create=

> test 'testParam 0.8010281114425616'
>    at junit.framework.TestResult$1=
.protect(TestResult.java:106)
> 
>    Can you please confirm that you actua=
lly tried the test
> suite I've sent? It generates 100 test cases using the=

> following suite() code:
> [...]

I found, upon looking into it, that Ecl=
ipse does have the /option/ 
of keeping the JUnit process/JVM running, so i=
t can restart 
individual test instances.

Eclipse 3.0.1 gives me this info=
rmative error message:
  "To rerun tests they must be launched under the de=
bugger
   and 'Keep JUnit running' must be set in the launch configuration"=


So this only works with DEBUG runs.  And then only if you enable 
it.  (A=
nd it can only be enabled if your JVM supports "hot code 
replacement.")  T=
his is not the default behavior.

(And *good luck* if you're using NetBeans=
, JBuilder or ant, and you 
want process and instance preservation across r=
uns!!!   ;-)

From "help" documentation:
  'A JUnit launch configuration ha=
s a "keep alive" option. If your 
Java virtual machine supports "hot code r=
eplacement" you can fix the 
code and rerun the test without restarting the=
 full test run. To 
enable this option select the Keep JUnit running after =
a test run 
when debugging checkbox in the JUnit launch configuration.'

..=
.

Otherwise, it launches a new process (new JVM, new test object 
instance=
s) on each JUnit run.

To see this behavior, select "Window -> Preferences"=
, "Run/Debug -> 
Launching" and uncheck the "Remove terminated launches whe=
n a new 
launch is created" option.

Then, in the "Debug" view (so you can =
see the list of processes, run 
a few tests.  Each one gets its own process=
.

Now it's true that when my 'suite()' method builds tests from 
standard =
TestCase classes with standard test methods, I can rerun 
any test class or=
 method with a right click, "Run".  But each one 
spawns a separate process=
.
